choices.C: Bidirectional PIM is designed to be used for one-to-many applications.
choices.A: Membership to a bidirectional group is signaled via explicit join messages.
choices.B: In Bidirectional PIM, the RP IP address can be shared with any other router interface.
choices.E: In Bidirectional PIM, the RP IP address does not need to be a router.
choices.D: A Cisco router cannot support all three PIM modes simultaneously.

questions.question_text:
An engineer set up a multicast design using all three Cisco supported PIM modes. Which two characteristics of Bidirectional PIM in this situation are true?
(Choose two.)

choices.B: Utilize the native VLAN only on trunk ports to reduce the risk of a Double-Tagged 802.1q VLAN hopping attack.
choices.E: Utilize the ARP inspection feature to help prevent the misuse of gARP.
choices.C: Utilize an access list to prevent the use of ARP to modify entries to the table.
choices.A: Utilize DHCP snooping on a per VLAN basis and apply ip dhcp snooping untrusted on all ports.
choices.D: Utilize private VLANs and ensure that all ports are part of the isolated port group.

discussion.content:
Interesting link about VLAN hoping attacks:
https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/blogs/vip-perspectives/2019/07/12/vlan1-and-vlan-hopping-attack
Wording however is tricky on answer B

questions.question_text: Which two security measures must an engineer follow when implementing Layer 2 and Layer 3 network design? (Choose two.)
An engineer is working on a design solution for a large hub-and-spoke EIGRP network. Which feature helps to make this design more stable while also reducing resource utilization?
Management has chosen to implement a top-of-the-rack data center design. Which two benefits of moving to this model are true? (Choose two.)

choices.B: fewer ports required in the aggregation
choices.D: directly connected racks in the row

discussion.content:
check this out this might shed light:
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en_us/solutions/industries/docs/gov/IntegNet_Feb17_915_Lynn.pdf
I think it's C. GETVPN. It is usually used in conjunction with MPLS VPNs and reuses the IP header.

questions.question_text: A company has a regulatory requirement that all connections between their sites must be encrypted in a manner that does not require maintenance of permanent tunnels. The remote offices are connected by a private MPLS-based service that requires a dynamically changing key, spoke-to-spoke communication, and reuse of the existing IP header. Which type of transport encryption must be used?
